author: jochembrouwer
content: I got a question since we are failing an EOF header test which I do not understand. The spec says the maximum number of container sections is 0x00FF. However, since the container section size itself has to start at the number 1 (by spec), does this mean that if I want to encode 255 (0xFF) container sections, I am actually allowed to use container section size 0x0100?

author: jochembrouwer
content: The test which we fail has 0x0100 container sections, and it is marked to pass (we fail). (So, in the container bytecode it has 0x0100 encoded)

author: jochembrouwer
content: By EIP 3540 this is not allowed though

author: _shemnon
content:
>  container section size itself has to start at the number 1 (by spec)
I don't think that's the case, EOFCREATE[0] and RETURNCONRACT[0] are very common stanzas in EEST.

author: jochembrouwer
content: EIP 3540

author: chfast
content: I think the "number of container sections" is confused here with "container section size". the "number of container sections" follows the sub-containers section kind (03) which is optional. So we want to avoid `03 0000` combination because `03` is optional.

author: _shemnon
content: So we will never see RETURNCONTRACT[255]?

author: jochembrouwer
content: I understand the 03 0000 thing, but the spec says that 03 0100 is not allowed

author: _shemnon
content: 03 0001 means one container, starting at index 0

author: jochembrouwer
content: And I assumed the containers are zero-indexed so

author: jochembrouwer
content: There is an EOF container test which is marked to be valid, but it has 03 0100 in it

author: chfast
content: Ah, ok I see what you mean. Maybe the spec should say `0x0001‚Äì0x0100`. And then `RETURNCONTRACT[255]` works.

author: jochembrouwer
content: I think so, yes

author: jochembrouwer
content: But I think then it should also note that the containers are zero-indexed because everything else in the spec is 1-indexed

author: chfast
content: evmone has `CONTAINER_SECTION_NUMBER_LIMIT = 256` üòâ

author: jochembrouwer
content: We have limit 255 üò¶ I'll change üôÇ

author: jochembrouwer
content: Should I open an issue for the spec?

author: jochembrouwer
content: Or I can just open a quick PR also

author: chfast
content: Yes, how you prefer.

author: pdobacz
content:
this, a little further down in the spec the maximum numbers of code/container sections are 1024 and 256 resp. (inclusive). The table is off

> - the number of code sections must be greater than `0` and not exceed `1024`
...
> - the number of container sections must not exceed `256`. The number of container sections may not be `0`, if declared in the header

author: pdobacz
content: I think the table mixes the theoretical ranges for 2-bytes integer with logical ones implied by the validation rules. Also the bullet points below duplicate the rules regarding admissible values from the table. Maybe we should fix the values in the table to logical ones (e.g. 0x0001-0x0100 for num containers) and remove the duplicate rules from the bullet points.

author: jochembrouwer
content:
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/8719
https://github.com/ipsilon/eof/pull/141

I just opened two prs üôÇ

author: jochembrouwer
content: If you want I can also remove those duplicate ones (but I think they are nice there, as a reminder for the reader)

author: pdobacz
content: no worries, I can play with this and see which option is the cleanest

author: jochembrouwer
content: When thinking about it, I think this option is the most consistent, since num code sections is also not 0-based (need at least one code section). So it makes sense to ban 0x03 0000

author: pdobacz
content: 0x030000 is banned

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ah right sorry I thought you meant that, but you mean the bullet points

author: pdobacz
content: yea I just mean layout and editing, and whether or not to duplicate the values

author: jochembrouwer
content: BTW, I have a question about the description of the stack validation with `min_stack_value` and `max_stack_value`.  Is there any scenario where those two values are not equal?

author: pdobacz
content: yup, offhand, so it might be off somewhat: ` ... RJUMPI[1] PUSH0 NOP`. Here at `NOP` you either PUSH0-ed or not, depending on the RJUMPI condition.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ahhh right of course

author: jochembrouwer
content:
But then does this section in mega EOF not need to get updated to use the same terms?

```
Otherwise instruction was already visited (by previously seen forward jump). Update this instruction's recorded stack height bounds so that they contain the bounds computed in 2.3, i.e. target_stack_min = min(target_stack_min, current_stack_min) and target_stack_max = max(target_stack_max, current_stack_max), where (target_stack_min, target_stack_max) are successor bounds and (current_stack_min, current_stack_max) are bounds computed in 2.3.
```

author: jochembrouwer
content: It seem to use both `min_stack_value` and `target_stack_min`

author: jochembrouwer
content: I'm assuming after seeing your argument that those vars are the same üôÇ

author: jochembrouwer
content: But I'm now just thinking out loud, can't you now not via a circular argument reason that you can create a body which stack overflows? ü§î

author: jochembrouwer
content: Oh wait we still check for overflows but not underflows

author: jochembrouwer
content: R-right?

author: pdobacz
content:
in runtime we only check overflow on CALLF/JUMPF, and there you can overflow. 

in eof validation you can detect under and overflow, that is, such code won't pass validation (should not üòÖ )

author: jochembrouwer
content: What if I try to deploy code to RJUMP to myself?

author: jochembrouwer
content: I'm sure I'm missing something obvious in the stack validation thing though üòÖ

author: pdobacz
content: you mean `PUSH0 RJUMP[-4]` ?

author: jochembrouwer
content: Yes something like that

author: pdobacz
content:
> 3. If the successor is reached via backwards jump, **check** if the recorded stack height bounds equal the value computed in 2.3. Validation fails if they are not equal, i.e. we see backwards jump to a different stack height.

in other words, jumping backwards ~~min_stack_height == max_stack_height~~ stack height bounds must be exactly the same for all "ways" to reach the destination, otherwise validation error

author: jochembrouwer
content: I see yes

author: pdobacz
content: sorry scratch that, fixing

author: pdobacz
content: fixed now. In the `NOP PUSH0 RJUMP[-4]` when you're reaching the PUSH0  from the NOP, you're one stack item less compared to when you're backwards RJUMPing.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Yes so min stack height / max stack height for that nop would both be 0, but for the backwards jump is 1, so this invalidates it?

author: pdobacz
content: correct

author: jochembrouwer
content: I see

author: jochembrouwer
content: Now I have to convince myself that this works üôÇ

author: jochembrouwer
content: BTW, the text in the stack validation (which you just copied) does not match what mega eof says, I think that one is correct?

author: jochembrouwer
content: (it does need the terminology update since it talks about the target_stack_min and not stack_height_min there) üòÖ

author: chfast
content: `RJUMP[-3]` jumps on itself (therefore valid). the `RJUMP[-4]` is invalid.

author: pdobacz
content: yea, I never remember this, fixing

author: pdobacz
content: so the previous example is off too, it is RJUMPI[1] that jumps over the next instruction if condition is satisfied. Fixed in the example too

author: jochembrouwer
content: Thanks üôÇ Yeah I got the idea from the description üëç

author: jochembrouwer
content: So just for my understanding, these min_stack and max_stack height divergences only happen on conditional jumps - right? So the only candidates here are RJUMPI and RJUMPV ?

author: _shemnon
content: And the design intent from the compilers is you would jump into a divergent section that would then revert/return/stop and exit.  So the differing heights don't get in the way of CALLF as you are jumping out of the current message frame

author: _shemnon
content: Otherwise you have duplicate terminal runs that differ only in validated stack height.

author: _shemnon
content: Or a bunch of swaps and pops before them.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Should have followed a compiler course at some point I think, but this does all make sense üôÇ

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ok I think I just convinced myself that this works

author: jochembrouwer
content: I was about to ask about underflows but realize that this is indeed also captured by same argument

author: jochembrouwer
content: How should I call the error when these stack heights diverge? "Unstable stack"? üòÜ
